   117	            block_hashes: Block hashes of the blocks in the request. Note that
   118	            this list may be shorter than the blocks list. In this case the
   119	            missed block hash will be computed in this function.
   120	            num_cached_blocks: The number of blocks that are already cached.
   121	            num_full_blocks: The number of blocks that are full and should
   122	                be cached after this function.
   123	            block_size: Number of tokens in each block.
   124	            kv_cache_group_id: The id of the KV cache group.
   125	            hash_fn: The hash function to use for block hashes.
   126	        """
   127	        if num_cached_blocks == num_full_blocks:
   128	            return
   129	        new_full_blocks = blocks[num_cached_blocks:num_full_blocks]
   130	        assert len(block_hashes) >= num_cached_blocks
   131	        new_block_hashes = block_hashes[num_cached_blocks:]
   132	
   133	        # Update the new blocks with the block hashes through the chain.
   134	        if num_cached_blocks == 0:
   135	            prev_block_hash_value = None
   136	        else:
   137	            prev_block = blocks[num_cached_blocks - 1]
   138	            assert prev_block.block_hash is not None
   139	            prev_block_hash_value = prev_block.block_hash.get_hash_value()
   140	
   141	        parent_block_hash = prev_block_hash_value
   142	        new_hashes: Optional[list[int]] = ([] if self.enable_kv_cache_events
   143	                                           else None)
   144	        for i, blk in enumerate(new_full_blocks):
   145	            assert blk.block_hash is None
   146	
   147	            if i < len(new_block_hashes):
   148	                # The block hash may already be computed in
   149	                # "get_computed_blocks" if the tokens are not generated by
   150	                # this request (either the prompt tokens or the previously
   151	                # generated tokens with preemption), or by other
   152	                # single_type_managers with the same block_size.
   153	                # In this case we simply reuse the block hash.
   154	                block_hash = new_block_hashes[i]
   155	            else:
   156	                # Otherwise compute the block hash and cache it in the request
   157	                # in case it will be preempted in the future.
   158	                blk_idx = num_cached_blocks + i
   159	                start_token_idx = blk_idx * block_size
   160	                end_token_idx = (blk_idx + 1) * block_size
   161	                block_tokens = request.all_token_ids[
   162	                    start_token_idx:end_token_idx]
   163	                assert len(block_tokens) == block_size, (
   164	                    f"Expected {block_size} tokens, got "
   165	                    f"{len(block_tokens)} at {blk_idx}th block for request "
   166	                    f"{request.request_id}({request})")
   167	
   168	                # Generate extra keys for multi-modal inputs. Note that since
   169	                # we reach to this branch only when the block is completed with
   170	                # generated tokens, we only need to consider the last mm input.
   171	                extra_keys, _ = generate_block_hash_extra_keys(
   172	                    request, start_token_idx, end_token_idx, -1)
   173	
   174	                # Compute the hash of the current block.
   175	                block_hash = hash_block_tokens(hash_fn, prev_block_hash_value,
   176	                                               block_tokens, extra_keys)
   177	                block_hashes.append(block_hash)
   178	
   179	            # Update and added the full block to the cache.
   180	            block_hash_with_group_id = BlockHashWithGroupId(
   181	                block_hash, kv_cache_group_id)
   182	            blk.block_hash = block_hash_with_group_id
   183	            self.cached_block_hash_to_block[block_hash_with_group_id][
   184	                blk.block_id] = blk
   185	            if new_hashes is not None:
   186	                new_hashes.append(block_hash.hash_value)
   187	            prev_block_hash_value = block_hash.hash_value
   188	
   189	        if self.enable_kv_cache_events:
   190	            self.kv_event_queue.append(
   191	                BlockStored(
   192	                    block_hashes=new_hashes,
   193	                    parent_block_hash=parent_block_hash,
   194	                    token_ids=request.
   195	                    all_token_ids[num_cached_blocks *
   196	                                  block_size:num_full_blocks * block_size],
   197	                    block_size=block_size,
   198	                    lora_id=request.lora_request.id
   199	                    if request.lora_request else None,
   200	                ))
   201	
   202	    def get_new_blocks(self, num_blocks: int) -> list[KVCacheBlock]:
   203	        """Get new blocks from the free block pool.
   204	
   205	        Note that we do not check block cache in this function.
   206	
   207	        Args:
   208	            num_blocks: The number of blocks to allocate.
   209	
   210	        Returns:
   211	            A list of new block.
   212	        """
   213	        if num_blocks > self.get_num_free_blocks():
   214	            raise ValueError(
   215	                f"Cannot get {num_blocks} free blocks from the pool")
   216	
   217	        ret: list[KVCacheBlock] = []
   218	        idx = 0
   219	        while idx < num_blocks:
   220	            # First allocate blocks.
   221	            curr_block = self.free_block_queue.popleft()
   222	            assert curr_block.ref_cnt == 0
   223	
   224	            # If the block is cached, evict it.
   225	            if self.enable_caching:
   226	                self._maybe_evict_cached_block(curr_block)
   227	
   228	            curr_block.incr_ref()
   229	            ret.append(curr_block)
   230	            idx += 1
   231	
   232	        return ret
   233	
   234	    def _maybe_evict_cached_block(self, block: KVCacheBlock) -> bool:
   235	        """
   236	        If a block is cached in `cached_block_hash_to_block`, we reset its hash
   237	        metadata and evict it from the cache.
   238	
   239	        Args:
   240	            block: The block to evict.
   241	
   242	        Returns:
   243	            True if the block is evicted, False otherwise.
   244	        """
   245	        block_hash = block.block_hash
   246	        if block_hash is None:
   247	            # The block doesn't have hash, eviction is not needed
   248	            return False
   249	        blocks_by_id = self.cached_block_hash_to_block.get(block_hash)
   250	        if blocks_by_id is None:
   251	            # block_hash not found in cached_block_hash_to_block,
   252	            # eviction is not needed
   253	            return False
   254	        block.reset_hash()
   255	        blocks_by_id.pop(block.block_id, None)
   256	        if len(blocks_by_id) == 0:
   257	            del self.cached_block_hash_to_block[block_hash]
   258	
   259	        if self.enable_kv_cache_events:
   260	            # FIXME (Chen): Not sure whether we should return `hash_value`
   261	            # or `(hash_value, group_id)` here. But it's fine now because
   262	            # we disable hybrid kv cache manager when kv cache event is
   263	            # enabled, so there is only one group.
   264	            self.kv_event_queue.append(
   265	                BlockRemoved(block_hashes=[block_hash.get_hash_value()]))
   266	        return True
   267	
   268	    def touch(self, blocks: tuple[list[KVCacheBlock], ...]) -> None:
   269	        """Touch a block increases its reference count by 1, and may remove
   270	        the block from the free queue. This is used when a block is hit by
   271	        another request with the same prefix.
   272	
   273	        Args:
   274	            blocks: A list of blocks to touch.
   275	        """
   276	        for blocks_per_group in blocks:
   277	            for block in blocks_per_group:
   278	                # ref_cnt=0 means this block is in the free list (i.e. eviction
   279	                # candidate), so remove it.
   280	                if block.ref_cnt == 0 and not block.is_null:
   281	                    self.free_block_queue.remove(block)
   282	                block.incr_ref()
   283	
   284	    def free_blocks(self, ordered_blocks: Iterable[KVCacheBlock]) -> None:
   285	        """Free a list of blocks. The blocks should be ordered by their
   286	        eviction priority, where the first block will be evicted first.
   287	
   288	        Args:
   289	            ordered_blocks: A list of blocks to free ordered by their eviction
   290	                priority.
   291	        """
   292	        for block in ordered_blocks:
   293	            block.decr_ref()
   294	            # null_block should not be added to the free list.
   295	            if block.ref_cnt == 0 and not block.is_null:
   296	                self.free_block_queue.append(block)
   297	
   298	    def reset_prefix_cache(self) -> bool:
   299	        """Reset prefix cache. This function may be used in RLHF
   300	        flows to invalid prefix caching after the weights are updated,
   301	        or used for resetting prefix caching status for benchmarking.
   302	
   303	        Returns:
   304	            bool: True if the prefix cache is successfully reset,
   305	            False otherwise.
   306	        """
   307	        num_used_blocks = self.num_gpu_blocks - self.get_num_free_blocks()
   308	        if num_used_blocks != 1:  # The null block is always marked as used
   309	            logger.warning(
   310	                "Failed to reset prefix cache because some "
   311	                "blocks (%d) are not freed yet", num_used_blocks - 1)
   312	            return False
   313	
   314	        # Remove all hashes so that no new blocks will hit.
   315	        self.cached_block_hash_to_block = defaultdict(dict)
   316	
   317	        # Remove all hashes from all blocks.
   318	        for block in self.blocks:
   319	            block.reset_hash()
   320	
   321	        logger.info("Successfully reset prefix cache")
   322	
   323	        if self.enable_kv_cache_events:
   324	            self.kv_event_queue.append(AllBlocksCleared())
   325	
   326	        return True
   327	
   328	    def get_num_free_blocks(self) -> int:
   329	        """Get the number of free blocks in the pool.
   330	
   331	        Returns:
   332	            The number of free blocks.
   333	        """
   334	        return self.free_block_queue.num_free_blocks
   335	
   336	    def get_usage(self) -> float:
   337	        """Get the KV cache usage.
   338	
   339	        Returns:
   340	            The KV cache usage (between 0.0 and 1.0).
   341	        """
   342	        return 1.0 - (self.get_num_free_blocks() / self.num_gpu_blocks)
   343	
   344	    def take_events(self) -> list[KVCacheEvent]:
   345	        """Atomically takes all events and clears the queue.
   346	        
   347	        Returns:
   348	            A list of KV cache events.
   349	        """
   350	        if not self.enable_kv_cache_events:
   351	            return []
   352	        events = self.kv_event_queue
   353	        self.kv_event_queue = []
   354	        return events

    76	class PrefixCachingMetrics:
    77	    """Metrics for prefix caching with a hit rate of the max recent N requests.
    78	
    79	    Args:
    80	        max_recent_requests: The number of the max recent requests to aggregate.
    81	            Defaults to 1000.
    82	    """
    83	
    84	    def __init__(self, max_recent_requests: int = 1000):
    85	        self.max_recent_requests = max_recent_requests
    86	        # The current aggregated values.
    87	        self.aggregated_requests = 0
    88	        self.aggregated_query_total = 0
    89	        self.aggregated_query_hit = 0
    90	        # A deque of (requests, queries, hits) for the most recent requests.
    91	        self.query_queue: deque[tuple[int, int, int]] = deque()
    92	
    93	    def observe(self, stats: PrefixCacheStats):
    94	        """Observe the prefix caching for a set of requests.
    95	
    96	        This function is called with information gathered when new requests
    97	        are being scheduled and are looking for computed blocks.
    98	
    99	        When there are more than `interval` requests, the oldest set of
   100	        requests are removed from the metrics.
   101	
   102	        Args:
   103	            stats: The prefix cache stats.
   104	        """
   105	        # reset_prefix_cache was invoked before the current update.
   106	        # Reset the metrics before aggregating the current stats.
   107	        if stats.reset:
   108	            self.reset()
   109	
   110	        # Update the metrics.
   111	        self.query_queue.append((stats.requests, stats.queries, stats.hits))
   112	        self.aggregated_requests += stats.requests
   113	        self.aggregated_query_total += stats.queries
   114	        self.aggregated_query_hit += stats.hits
   115	
   116	        # Remove the oldest stats if the number of requests exceeds.
   117	        if self.aggregated_requests > self.max_recent_requests:
   118	            old_requests, old_queries, old_hits = self.query_queue.popleft()
   119	            self.aggregated_requests -= old_requests
   120	            self.aggregated_query_total -= old_queries
   121	            self.aggregated_query_hit -= old_hits
   122	
   123	    def reset(self):
   124	        """Reset the metrics."""
   125	        self.aggregated_requests = 0
   126	        self.aggregated_query_total = 0
   127	        self.aggregated_query_hit = 0
   128	        self.query_queue.clear()
   129	
   130	    @property
   131	    def hit_rate(self) -> float:
   132	        """Calculate the hit rate for the past N requests."""
   133	        if self.aggregated_query_total == 0:
   134	            return 0.0
   135	        return self.aggregated_query_hit / self.aggregated_query_total

   191	class FreeKVCacheBlockQueue:
   192	    """This class organizes a list of KVCacheBlock objects to a doubly linked
   193	    list of free blocks. We implement this class instead of using Python
   194	    builtin deque to support removing a block in the middle of the queue
   195	    in O(1) time. To close the performance gap to the builtin deque which is
   196	    implemented in C++, this class does not allocate any Python objects when
   197	    manipulating the linked list. Instead, this class manipulates the
   198	    prev_free_block and next_free_block attributes of the given blocks.
   199	
   200	    The queue is ordered by block ID in the beginning. When a block is allocated
   201	    and then freed, it will be appended back with the eviction order:
   202	    1. The least recent used block is at the front (LRU).
   203	    2. If two blocks have the same last accessed time (allocated by the
   204	       same sequence), the one with more hash tokens (the tail of a block
   205	       chain) is at the front.
   206	    Note that we maintain this order by reversing the block order when free
   207	    blocks of a request. This operation is outside of this class.
   208	
   209	    Args:
   210	        blocks: A list of KVCacheBlock objects.
   211	    """
   212	
   213	    def __init__(self, blocks: list[KVCacheBlock]) -> None:
   214	        self.num_free_blocks = len(blocks)
   215	
   216	        # Initialize doubly links of consecutive blocks
   217	        for i in range(self.num_free_blocks):
   218	            if i > 0:
   219	                blocks[i].prev_free_block = blocks[i - 1]
   220	            if i < self.num_free_blocks - 1:
   221	                blocks[i].next_free_block = blocks[i + 1]
   222	
   223	        # Create a fake head and a tail block for the doubly linked list to
   224	        # reduce branching in the code
   225	        #
   226	        # The implementation garenteed that the fake head and tail
   227	        # are NEVER got popped, so we could safely assume each real blocks
   228	        # in the queue has prev and next blocks.
   229	        self.fake_free_list_head = KVCacheBlock(block_id=-1)
   230	        self.fake_free_list_tail = KVCacheBlock(block_id=-1)
   231	        if self.num_free_blocks > 0:
   232	            # Connect fake_head and fake_tail to the first and last block
   233	            # respectively.
   234	            self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block = blocks[0]
   235	            blocks[0].prev_free_block = self.fake_free_list_head
   236	            self.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block = blocks[-1]
   237	            blocks[-1].next_free_block = self.fake_free_list_tail
   238	        else:
   239	            # For empty list, simply connect the fake head and tail.
   240	            self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block = self.fake_free_list_tail
   241	            self.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block = self.fake_free_list_head
   242	
   243	    def popleft(self) -> KVCacheBlock:
   244	        """Pop the first free block and reduce num_free_blocks by 1.
   245	
   246	        Returns:
   247	            The first free block.
   248	        """
   249	        if (self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block
   250	                is self.fake_free_list_tail
   251	                or self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block is None):
   252	            assert self.num_free_blocks == 0, (
   253	                f"num_free_blocks ({self.num_free_blocks}) is out of sync "
   254	                "with the free list.")
   255	            raise ValueError("No free blocks available")
   256	
   257	        first_block: KVCacheBlock = self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block
   258	
   259	        if first_block.next_free_block is None:
   260	            # This should not happen if the block is from the free list.
   261	            # It indicates a bug in the caller's logic.
   262	            raise RuntimeError("Invalid block found in popleft() "
   263	                               "which doesn't have a valid next_free_block")
   264	
   265	        # Connect fake_head and the next block of first_block (i.e. second block
   266	        # or fake tail).
   267	        self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block = first_block.next_free_block
   268	        first_block.next_free_block.prev_free_block = self.fake_free_list_head
   269	
   270	        # Remove the block from the linked list.
   271	        first_block.prev_free_block = first_block.next_free_block = None
   272	
   273	        self.num_free_blocks -= 1
   274	        return first_block
   275	
   276	    def remove(self, block: KVCacheBlock) -> None:
   277	        """Remove a block in the free list and reduce num_free_blocks by 1.
   278	
   279	        Args:
   280	            block: The block to remove.
   281	        """
   282	        if block.prev_free_block is None or block.next_free_block is None:
   283	            # This should not happen if the block is from the free list.
   284	            # It indicates a bug in the caller's logic.
   285	            raise RuntimeError(f"remove() called on an invalid block: {block}")
   286	
   287	        # Link the previous block to the next block.
   288	        block.prev_free_block.next_free_block = block.next_free_block
   289	        # Link the next block to the previous block.
   290	        block.next_free_block.prev_free_block = block.prev_free_block
   291	
   292	        # Remove the block from the linked list.
   293	        block.prev_free_block = block.next_free_block = None

    76	class PrefixCachingMetrics:
    77	    """Metrics for prefix caching with a hit rate of the max recent N requests.
    78	
    79	    Args:
    80	        max_recent_requests: The number of the max recent requests to aggregate.
    81	            Defaults to 1000.
    82	    """
    83	
    84	    def __init__(self, max_recent_requests: int = 1000):
    85	        self.max_recent_requests = max_recent_requests
    86	        # The current aggregated values.
    87	        self.aggregated_requests = 0
    88	        self.aggregated_query_total = 0
    89	        self.aggregated_query_hit = 0
    90	        # A deque of (requests, queries, hits) for the most recent requests.
    91	        self.query_queue: deque[tuple[int, int, int]] = deque()
    92	
    93	    def observe(self, stats: PrefixCacheStats):
    94	        """Observe the prefix caching for a set of requests.
    95	
    96	        This function is called with information gathered when new requests
    97	        are being scheduled and are looking for computed blocks.
    98	
    99	        When there are more than `interval` requests, the oldest set of
   100	        requests are removed from the metrics.
   101	
   102	        Args:
   103	            stats: The prefix cache stats.
   104	        """
   105	        # reset_prefix_cache was invoked before the current update.
   106	        # Reset the metrics before aggregating the current stats.
   107	        if stats.reset:
   108	            self.reset()
   109	
   110	        # Update the metrics.
   111	        self.query_queue.append((stats.requests, stats.queries, stats.hits))
   112	        self.aggregated_requests += stats.requests
   113	        self.aggregated_query_total += stats.queries
   114	        self.aggregated_query_hit += stats.hits
   115	
   116	        # Remove the oldest stats if the number of requests exceeds.
   117	        if self.aggregated_requests > self.max_recent_requests:
   118	            old_requests, old_queries, old_hits = self.query_queue.popleft()
   119	            self.aggregated_requests -= old_requests
   120	            self.aggregated_query_total -= old_queries
   121	            self.aggregated_query_hit -= old_hits
   122	
   123	    def reset(self):
   124	        """Reset the metrics."""
   125	        self.aggregated_requests = 0
   126	        self.aggregated_query_total = 0
   127	        self.aggregated_query_hit = 0
   128	        self.query_queue.clear()
   129	
   130	    @property
   131	    def hit_rate(self) -> float:
   132	        """Calculate the hit rate for the past N requests."""
   133	        if self.aggregated_query_total == 0:
   134	            return 0.0
   135	        return self.aggregated_query_hit / self.aggregated_query_total

   191	class FreeKVCacheBlockQueue:
   192	    """This class organizes a list of KVCacheBlock objects to a doubly linked
   193	    list of free blocks. We implement this class instead of using Python
   194	    builtin deque to support removing a block in the middle of the queue
   195	    in O(1) time. To close the performance gap to the builtin deque which is
   196	    implemented in C++, this class does not allocate any Python objects when
   197	    manipulating the linked list. Instead, this class manipulates the
   198	    prev_free_block and next_free_block attributes of the given blocks.
   199	
   200	    The queue is ordered by block ID in the beginning. When a block is allocated
   201	    and then freed, it will be appended back with the eviction order:
   202	    1. The least recent used block is at the front (LRU).
   203	    2. If two blocks have the same last accessed time (allocated by the
   204	       same sequence), the one with more hash tokens (the tail of a block
   205	       chain) is at the front.
   206	    Note that we maintain this order by reversing the block order when free
   207	    blocks of a request. This operation is outside of this class.
   208	
   209	    Args:
   210	        blocks: A list of KVCacheBlock objects.
   211	    """
   212	
   213	    def __init__(self, blocks: list[KVCacheBlock]) -> None:
   214	        self.num_free_blocks = len(blocks)
   215	
   216	        # Initialize doubly links of consecutive blocks
   217	        for i in range(self.num_free_blocks):
   218	            if i > 0:
   219	                blocks[i].prev_free_block = blocks[i - 1]
   220	            if i < self.num_free_blocks - 1:
   221	                blocks[i].next_free_block = blocks[i + 1]
   222	
   223	        # Create a fake head and a tail block for the doubly linked list to
   224	        # reduce branching in the code
   225	        #
   226	        # The implementation garenteed that the fake head and tail
   227	        # are NEVER got popped, so we could safely assume each real blocks
   228	        # in the queue has prev and next blocks.
   229	        self.fake_free_list_head = KVCacheBlock(block_id=-1)
   230	        self.fake_free_list_tail = KVCacheBlock(block_id=-1)
   231	        if self.num_free_blocks > 0:
   232	            # Connect fake_head and fake_tail to the first and last block
   233	            # respectively.
   234	            self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block = blocks[0]
   235	            blocks[0].prev_free_block = self.fake_free_list_head
   236	            self.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block = blocks[-1]
   237	            blocks[-1].next_free_block = self.fake_free_list_tail
   238	        else:
   239	            # For empty list, simply connect the fake head and tail.
   240	            self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block = self.fake_free_list_tail
   241	            self.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block = self.fake_free_list_head
   242	
   243	    def popleft(self) -> KVCacheBlock:
   244	        """Pop the first free block and reduce num_free_blocks by 1.
   245	
   246	        Returns:
   247	            The first free block.
   248	        """
   249	        if (self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block
   250	                is self.fake_free_list_tail
   251	                or self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block is None):
   252	            assert self.num_free_blocks == 0, (
   253	                f"num_free_blocks ({self.num_free_blocks}) is out of sync "
   254	                "with the free list.")
   255	            raise ValueError("No free blocks available")
   256	
   257	        first_block: KVCacheBlock = self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block
   258	
   259	        if first_block.next_free_block is None:
   260	            # This should not happen if the block is from the free list.
   261	            # It indicates a bug in the caller's logic.
   262	            raise RuntimeError("Invalid block found in popleft() "
   263	                               "which doesn't have a valid next_free_block")
   264	
   265	        # Connect fake_head and the next block of first_block (i.e. second block
   266	        # or fake tail).
   267	        self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block = first_block.next_free_block
   268	        first_block.next_free_block.prev_free_block = self.fake_free_list_head
   269	
   270	        # Remove the block from the linked list.
   271	        first_block.prev_free_block = first_block.next_free_block = None
   272	
   273	        self.num_free_blocks -= 1
   274	        return first_block
   275	
   276	    def remove(self, block: KVCacheBlock) -> None:
   277	        """Remove a block in the free list and reduce num_free_blocks by 1.

    54	class PrefixCachingBlockAllocator(BlockAllocator):
    55	    """A block allocator that implements prefix caching.
    56	
    57	    The PrefixCachingBlockAllocator maintains a cache of blocks based on their
    58	    content hash. It reuses blocks with the same content hash to avoid redundant
    59	    memory allocation. The allocator also supports copy-on-write operations.
    60	
    61	    Args:
    62	        num_blocks (int): The total number of blocks to manage.
    63	        block_size (int): The size of each block in tokens.
    64	        block_ids(Optional[Iterable[int]], optional): An optional iterable of
    65	            block IDs. If not provided, block IDs will be assigned sequentially
    66	            from 0 to num_blocks - 1.
    67	    """
    68	
    69	    # Note that we use 'None' as a string here instead of None because
    70	    # as of Python 3.12, hash(None) returns a constant predictable value.
    71	    # This could possibly make it easier to find and exploit hash
    72	    # collisions. 'None' as a string will be hashed differently per process,
    73	    # but consistently within the same process. This is the same as the
    74	    # behavior of None prior to Python 3.12.
    75	    _none_hash: int = hash('None')
    76	
    77	    # Implements Block.Factory.
    78	    def __init__(
    79	        self,
    80	        num_blocks: int,
    81	        block_size: int,
    82	        block_ids: Optional[Iterable[int]] = None,
    83	        eviction_policy: EvictionPolicy = EvictionPolicy.LRU,
    84	    ):
    85	        if block_ids is None:
    86	            block_ids = range(num_blocks)
    87	
    88	        self._block_size = block_size
    89	
    90	        # A mapping of prefix hash to block index. All blocks which have a
    91	        # prefix hash will be in this dict, even if they have refcount 0.
    92	        self._cached_blocks: Dict[PrefixHash, BlockId] = {}
    93	
    94	        # A list of immutable block IDs that have been touched by scheduler
    95	        # and should be marked as computed after an entire batch of sequences
    96	        # are scheduled.
    97	        self._touched_blocks: Set[BlockId] = set()
    98	
    99	        # Used to track status of each physical block id
   100	        self._block_tracker: Dict[BlockId, BlockTracker] = {}
   101	        for block_id in block_ids:
   102	            self._block_tracker[block_id] = BlockTracker()
   103	
   104	        # Pre-allocate "num_blocks * extra_factor" block objects.
   105	        # The "* extra_factor" is a buffer to allow more block objects
   106	        # than physical blocks
   107	        extra_factor = 4
   108	        self._block_pool = BlockPool(self._block_size, self._create_block,
   109	                                     self, num_blocks * extra_factor)
   110	
   111	        # An allocator for blocks that do not have prefix hashes.
   112	        self._hashless_allocator = NaiveBlockAllocator(
   113	            create_block=self._create_block,  # type: ignore
   114	            num_blocks=num_blocks,
   115	            block_size=block_size,
   116	            block_ids=block_ids,
   117	            block_pool=self._block_pool,  # Share block pool here
   118	        )
   119	
   120	        # Evitor used to maintain how we want to handle those computed blocks
   121	        # if we find memory pressure is high.
   122	        self.eviction_policy = eviction_policy
   123	        self.evictor: Evictor = make_evictor(self.eviction_policy)
   124	
   125	        # We share the refcounter between allocators. This allows us to promote
   126	        # blocks originally allocated in the hashless allocator to immutable
   127	        # blocks.
   128	        self._refcounter = self._hashless_allocator.refcounter
   129

   393	def test_metrics():
   394	    """
   395	    Test the prefix caching metrics.
   396	    """
   397	
   398	    def stats(requests, queries, hits):
   399	        return PrefixCacheStats(requests=requests, queries=queries, hits=hits)
   400	
   401	    metrics = PrefixCachingMetrics(max_recent_requests=5)
   402	    assert metrics.hit_rate == 0.0
   403	
   404	    metrics.observe(stats(1, 20, 9))
   405	    # 9 / 20 = 0.45
   406	    assert metrics.hit_rate == 0.45
   407	
   408	    metrics.observe(stats(4, 80, 16))
   409	
   410	    # 25 / 100 = 0.25
   411	    assert metrics.hit_rate == 0.25
   412	
   413	    metrics.observe(stats(1, 10, 2))

    def find_cached_blocks_prefix(self, block_hashes: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        """
        Given a list of block hashes, return the prefix of the block hashes that
        are all cached.

        Since a block's block hash includes the hashes of all previous blocks,
        and we only allocate/deallocate blocks in the entire sequence, so if a
        block is cached, then all previous blocks are also cached. With this
        property, we can use binary search to find the prefix of cached blocks.

        Args:
            block_hashes (List[int]): The list of block hashes.

        Returns:
            List[int]: The prefix of the `block_hashes` that are cached.
        """

        def _block_is_cached(block_hash: PrefixHash) -> bool:
            if block_hash not in self._cached_blocks:
                return False

            cached_block_id = self._cached_blocks[block_hash]
            # We only consider the blocks that are marked as computed.
            return self.block_is_computed(cached_block_id)

        def _bisect_left(a, x, key: Callable[[PrefixHash], bool]) -> int:

            # python <= 3.10 don't have the key argument
            if sys.version_info < (3, 10):
                a = [key(e) for e in a]
                return bisect_left(a, x)
            else:
                return bisect_left(a, x, key=key)

        # Look for the first block that's not cached, and returns the prefix
        # i.e. blocks that are cached.
        idx = _bisect_left(block_hashes,
                           True,
                           key=lambda x: not _block_is_cached(x))
        return block_hashes[:idx]


class PrefixCachingBlock(Block):
    """A block implementation that supports prefix caching.

    The PrefixCachingBlock class represents a block of token IDs with prefix
    caching capabilities. It wraps a NaiveBlock internally and provides
    additional functionality for content hashing and promoting immutable blocks
    with the prefix caching allocator.

    Args:
        prev_block (Optional[PrefixCachingBlock]): The previous block in the
            sequence.
        token_ids (List[int]): The initial token IDs to be stored in the block.
        block_size (int): The maximum number of token IDs that can be stored in
            the block.
        allocator (BlockAllocator): The prefix
            caching block allocator associated with this block.
        block_id (Optional[int], optional): The physical block index
            of this block. Defaults to None.
        extra_hash (Optional[int]): The hash value of additional factors
            such as adapters that influence the block, apart from the token_ids.
    """

    # Note that we use 'None' as a string here instead of None because
    # as of Python 3.12, hash(None) returns a constant predictable value.
    # This could possibly make it easier to find and exploit hash
    # collisions. 'None' as a string will be hashed differently per process,
    # but consistently within the same process. This is the same as the
    # behavior of None prior to Python 3.12.
    _none_hash: int = hash('None')

    def __init__(
        self,
        prev_block: Optional[Block],
        token_ids: List[int],
        block_size: int,
        allocator: BlockAllocator,
        block_id: Optional[int] = None,
        computed: bool = False,
        extra_hash: Optional[int] = None,
    ):
        assert isinstance(allocator, PrefixCachingBlockAllocator), (
            "Currently this class is only tested with "
            "PrefixCachingBlockAllocator. Got instead allocator = {}".format(
                allocator))
        assert_prefix_caching_block_or_none(prev_block)

        self._prev_block = prev_block
        self._cached_content_hash: Optional[int] = None
        self._cached_num_tokens_total: int = 0
        self._allocator = allocator
        self._last_accessed: float = _DEFAULT_LAST_ACCESSED_TIME
        self._computed = computed
        self._extra_hash = extra_hash

        # On the first time, we create the block object, and next we only
        # reinitialize it
        if hasattr(self, "_block"):
            self._block.__init__(  # type: ignore[has-type]
                prev_block=prev_block,
                token_ids=token_ids,
                block_size=block_size,
                block_id=block_id,
                allocator=self._allocator)
        else:
            self._block = NaiveBlock(prev_block=prev_block,
                                     token_ids=token_ids,
                                     block_size=block_size,
                                     block_id=block_id,
                                     allocator=self._allocator)

        self._update_num_tokens_total()

    def _update_num_tokens_total(self):
        """Incrementally computes the number of tokens that there is
        till the current block (included)
        """
        res = 0

        # Add all previous blocks
        if self._prev_block is not None:
            res += self._prev_block.num_tokens_total

        # Add current block
        res += len(self.token_ids)

        self._cached_num_tokens_total = res

    @property
    def computed(self) -> bool:
        return self._computed

    @computed.setter
    def computed(self, value) -> None:
        self._computed = value

    @property
    def last_accessed(self) -> float:
        return self._last_accessed

    @last_accessed.setter
    def last_accessed(self, last_accessed_ts: float):
        self._last_accessed = last_accessed_ts

    def append_token_ids(self, token_ids: List[int]) -> None:
        """Appends the given token IDs to the block and registers the block as
        immutable if the block becomes full.

        Args:
            token_ids (List[int]): The token IDs to be appended to the block.
        """
        # Ensure this is mutable block (not promoted)
        assert self.content_hash is None
        assert not self.computed

        if len(token_ids) == 0:
            return

        # Ensure there are input tokens
        assert token_ids, "Got token_ids = {}".format(token_ids)

        # Naive block handles CoW.
        self._block.append_token_ids(token_ids)
        self._update_num_tokens_total()

        # If the content hash is present, then the block can be made immutable.
        # Register ourselves with the allocator, potentially replacing the
        # physical block index.
        if self.content_hash is not None:
            self.block_id = self._allocator.promote_to_immutable_block(self)

    @property
    def block_id(self) -> Optional[int]:
        return self._block.block_id

        """

    def append_token_ids(self, token_ids: List[int]) -> None:
        """Appends the given token IDs to the block and registers the block as
        immutable if the block becomes full.

        Args:
            token_ids (List[int]): The token IDs to be appended to the block.
        """
        # Ensure this is mutable block (not promoted)
        assert self.content_hash is None
        assert not self.computed

        if len(token_ids) == 0:
            return

        # Ensure there are input tokens
        assert token_ids, "Got token_ids = {}".format(token_ids)

        # Naive block handles CoW.
        self._block.append_token_ids(token_ids)
        self._update_num_tokens_total()

        # If the content hash is present, then the block can be made immutable.
        # Register ourselves with the allocator, potentially replacing the
        # physical block index.
        if self.content_hash is not None:
            self.block_id = self._allocator.promote_to_immutable_block(self)

    @property
    def block_id(self) -> Optional[int]:
        return self._block.block_id

llm_response.content: I will implement batch operations popleft_n and append_n in v1 FreeKVCacheBlockQueue, and update BlockPool to use them for fewer pointer updates and Python-level overhead. Then I'll add tests for these new methods. These changes modify repository files.

arguments.new_str:
def popleft_n(self, n: int) -> list[KVCacheBlock]:
        """Pop up to n free blocks from the head in a single splice.

        Args:
            n: Maximum number of blocks to pop.

        Returns:
            A list of popped blocks in order from head to tail.
        """
        if n <= 0:
            return []
        if (self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block is self.fake_free_list_tail
                or self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block is None):
            assert self.num_free_blocks == 0, (
                f"num_free_blocks ({self.num_free_blocks}) is out of sync "
                "with the free list.")
            raise ValueError("No free blocks available")

        # Determine the actual number of blocks to pop and the tail of the slice.
        first_block: KVCacheBlock = self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block  # type: ignore[assignment]
        count = 1
        tail_block = first_block
        while count < n and tail_block.next_free_block is not None \
                and tail_block.next_free_block is not self.fake_free_list_tail:
            tail_block = tail_block.next_free_block
            count += 1

        # Detach [first_block, ..., tail_block] from the free list by splicing.
        next_after_tail = tail_block.next_free_block  # could be fake tail
        assert next_after_tail is not None
        self.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block = next_after_tail
        next_after_tail.prev_free_block = self.fake_free_list_head

        # Collect popped blocks and clear their free-list links.
        popped: list[KVCacheBlock] = []
        curr = first_block
        while True:
            next_curr = curr.next_free_block
            curr.prev_free_block = None
            curr.next_free_block = None
            popped.append(curr)
            if curr is tail_block:
                break
            assert next_curr is not None
            curr = next_curr

        self.num_free_blocks -= count
        return popped

    def append_n(self, blocks: list[KVCacheBlock]) -> None:
        """Append a list of blocks to the tail in a single splice.

        Args:
            blocks: The blocks to append in order.
        """
        if not blocks:
            return
        if self.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block is None:
            raise RuntimeError(
                "prev_free_block of fake_free_list_tail should always exist")
        last_block: KVCacheBlock = self.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block

        # Link the first new block after the current last block.
        first_new = blocks[0]
        last_block.next_free_block = first_new
        first_new.prev_free_block = last_block

        # Chain the internal blocks.
        for i in range(len(blocks) - 1):
            a = blocks[i]
            b = blocks[i + 1]
            a.next_free_block = b
            b.prev_free_block = a

        # Link the last new block to the fake tail.
        last_new = blocks[-1]
        last_new.next_free_block = self.fake_free_list_tail
        self.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block = last_new

        self.num_free_blocks += len(blocks)
arguments.old_str:
def append(self, block: KVCacheBlock) -> None:
        """Put a block back into the free list and increase
        num_free_blocks by 1.

        Args:
            block: The block to append.
        """
        if self.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block is None:
            raise RuntimeError(
                "prev_free_block of fake_free_list_tail should always exist")
        last_block: KVCacheBlock = self.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block

        # Connect the new block after the last block.
        last_block.next_free_block = block
        block.prev_free_block = last_block

        # Connect the fake tail after the new block.
        block.next_free_block = self.fake_free_list_tail
        self.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block = block

        self.num_free_blocks += 1

        """Append a single block to the tail.
        This is a compatibility wrapper around append_n.
        """
        self.append_n([block])

arguments.new_str:
def test_free_kv_cache_block_queue_append_n():
    # Create an empty FreeKVCacheBlockQueue
    queue = FreeKVCacheBlockQueue([])
    blocks = [KVCacheBlock(block_id=i) for i in range(6)]

    # Append 0 blocks: still empty
    queue.append_n([])
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 0
    assert (queue.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block
            is queue.fake_free_list_tail)
    assert (queue.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block
            is queue.fake_free_list_head)

    # Append 1 block
    queue.append_n(blocks[0:1])
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 1
    assert queue.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block is blocks[0]
    assert blocks[0].prev_free_block is queue.fake_free_list_head
    assert blocks[0].next_free_block is queue.fake_free_list_tail
    assert queue.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block is blocks[0]

    # Append 2 more blocks
    queue.append_n(blocks[1:3])
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 3
    assert queue.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block is blocks[0]
    assert blocks[0].next_free_block is blocks[1]
    assert blocks[1].prev_free_block is blocks[0]
    assert blocks[1].next_free_block is blocks[2]
    assert blocks[2].prev_free_block is blocks[1]
    assert blocks[2].next_free_block is queue.fake_free_list_tail
    assert queue.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block is blocks[2]

    # Append a single block again
    queue.append(blocks[3])
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 4
    assert queue.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block is blocks[3]
    assert blocks[3].prev_free_block is blocks[2]
    assert blocks[3].next_free_block is queue.fake_free_list_tail


def test_free_kv_cache_block_queue_popleft_n():
    # Initialize 6 blocks in queue
    blocks = [KVCacheBlock(block_id=i) for i in range(6)]
    queue = FreeKVCacheBlockQueue(blocks)

    # Pop zero returns empty
    popped0 = queue.popleft_n(0)
    assert popped0 == []
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 6

    # Pop two
    popped = queue.popleft_n(2)
    assert [b.block_id for b in popped] == [0, 1]
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 4
    assert queue.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block is blocks[2]
    # Ensure popped blocks are detached
    assert all(b.prev_free_block is None and b.next_free_block is None
               for b in popped)

    # Pop the rest
    popped_rest = queue.popleft_n(10)
    assert [b.block_id for b in popped_rest] == [2, 3, 4, 5]
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 0
    assert (queue.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block
            is queue.fake_free_list_tail)
    assert (queue.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block
            is queue.fake_free_list_head)

    # Now any popleft should error
    with pytest.raises(ValueError):
        queue.popleft()

def test_free_kv_cache_block_queue_append_n():
    # Create an empty FreeKVCacheBlockQueue
    queue = FreeKVCacheBlockQueue([])
    blocks = [KVCacheBlock(block_id=i) for i in range(6)]

    # Append 0 blocks: still empty
    queue.append_n([])
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 0
    assert (queue.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block
            is queue.fake_free_list_tail)
    assert (queue.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block
            is queue.fake_free_list_head)

    # Append 1 block
    queue.append_n(blocks[0:1])
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 1
    assert queue.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block is blocks[0]
    assert blocks[0].prev_free_block is queue.fake_free_list_head
    assert blocks[0].next_free_block is queue.fake_free_list_tail
    assert queue.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block is blocks[0]

    # Append 2 more blocks
    queue.append_n(blocks[1:3])
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 3
    assert queue.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block is blocks[0]
    assert blocks[0].next_free_block is blocks[1]
    assert blocks[1].prev_free_block is blocks[0]
    assert blocks[1].next_free_block is blocks[2]
    assert blocks[2].prev_free_block is blocks[1]
    assert blocks[2].next_free_block is queue.fake_free_list_tail
    assert queue.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block is blocks[2]

    # Append a single block again
    queue.append(blocks[3])
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 4
    assert queue.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block is blocks[3]
    assert blocks[3].prev_free_block is blocks[2]
    assert blocks[3].next_free_block is queue.fake_free_list_tail


def test_free_kv_cache_block_queue_popleft_n():
    # Initialize 6 blocks in queue
    blocks = [KVCacheBlock(block_id=i) for i in range(6)]
    queue = FreeKVCacheBlockQueue(blocks)

    # Pop zero returns empty
    popped0 = queue.popleft_n(0)
    assert popped0 == []
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 6

    # Pop two
    popped = queue.popleft_n(2)
    assert [b.block_id for b in popped] == [0, 1]
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 4
    assert queue.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block is blocks[2]
    # Ensure popped blocks are detached
    assert all(b.prev_free_block is None and b.next_free_block is None
               for b in popped)

    # Pop the rest
    popped_rest = queue.popleft_n(10)
    assert [b.block_id for b in popped_rest] == [2, 3, 4, 5]
    assert queue.num_free_blocks == 0
    assert (queue.fake_free_list_head.next_free_block
            is queue.fake_free_list_tail)
    assert (queue.fake_free_list_tail.prev_free_block
            is queue.fake_free_list_head)

    # Now any popleft should error
    with pytest.raises(ValueError):
        queue.popleft()

import time
from vllm.core.block.prefix_caching_block import PrefixCachingBlockAllocator

# Benchmark prefix caching block allocation with common prefixes
block_size = 16
num_blocks = 256
num_sequences = 8
common_prefix_blocks = 4

# Create allocator
allocator = PrefixCachingBlockAllocator(num_blocks=num_blocks, block_size=block_size)

# Common token IDs for shared prefix
common_token_ids = list(range(block_size * common_prefix_blocks))

# Time the allocation and marking operation
start = time.time()

# Allocate blocks for multiple sequences with common prefixes
for seq_idx in range(num_sequences):
    prev_block = None
    for block_idx in range(common_prefix_blocks):
        start_idx = block_idx * block_size
        end_idx = start_idx + block_size

import time
from vllm.core.block.prefix_caching_block import PrefixCachingBlockAllocator

# Benchmark prefix caching block allocation with common prefixes
block_size = 16
num_blocks = 256
num_sequences = 8
common_prefix_blocks = 4

# Create allocator
allocator = PrefixCachingBlockAllocator(num_blocks=num_blocks, block_size=block_size)

# Common token IDs for shared prefix
common_token_ids = list(range(block_size * common_prefix_blocks))

# Time the allocation and marking operation
start = time.time()

# Allocate blocks for multiple sequences with common prefixes
for seq_idx in range(num_sequences):
    prev_block = None
    for block_idx in range(common_prefix_blocks):
        start_idx = block_idx * block_size
        end_idx = start_idx + block_size
        token_ids = common_token_ids[start_idx:end_idx]

        block = allocator.allocate_immutable_block(
            prev_block=prev_block,
            token_ids=token_ids
        )
        prev_block = block

# Mark blocks as computed (this is the optimized operation)
allocator.mark_blocks_as_computed([])

duration = time.time() - start
print(f"Duration: {duration:.4f} seconds")
print(f"Cache hit rate: {allocator.get_prefix_cache_hit_rate():.3f}")
